content.question: A student collects two data points for a sample of a gas that can be treated as ideal and is in a rigid container: <math alttext="T sub 1 equals 300 Kelvin " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>300</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="P sub 1 equals 3.0 kilopascals " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>kPa</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="T sub 2 equals 310 Kelvin " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>310</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="P sub 2 equals 3.1 kilopascals " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3.1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>kPa</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following is the best conclusion about the pressure of an ideal gas at absolute zero (that is, <math alttext="T equals 0 Kelvin " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) that can be made from this data?

choices.label: The pressure is <math alttext="0 kilopascals " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>kPa</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
No conclusion can be made, because a pattern cannot be validated based on only two data points.
No conclusion can be made, because the substance is no longer a gas near absolute zero.

No conclusion can be made, because the volume of the gas is zero at absolute zero, and <math alttext="P V equals 0 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>V</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>=</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> does not necessarily imply that pressure is zero.
